title: Pollination service playbook (placement, acceptance checks, SLAs)
At-a-Glance: Professional pollination runs on clear roles and repeatable checklists. Agree hive strength definitions and inspection rights, map placements and water sources, set no-spray windows with notification protocols, and document delivery/collection. On arrival, complete acceptance checks (strength, health, queen-right) with signatures from both sides. During bloom, keep comms short and factual—weather, spray intentions, issues. If a spray incident happens, stop, document thoroughly and escalate per contract. A tidy playbook prevents misunderstandings and keeps fruit, farmer and beekeeper aligned.
Why it Matters: Pollination is where beekeeping meets agriculture’s moving parts—sprays, irrigation, labour, deadlines. Vague expectations produce conflict: growers expect instant strength; beekeepers expect perfect spray timing; neither gets what they want. A written playbook with SLAs fixes this. Strength metrics and acceptance checks set the baseline; placement and water keep bees where they help most; notification clauses and indemnities turn ‘we hoped’ into ‘we agreed’. When something goes wrong (it will, someday), a pre-agreed incident pathway keeps relationships intact and insurers cooperative. The result is repeat business and calmer seasons for both parties—more fruit set, fewer 2 a.m. phone calls, and bees that work rather than wander.
Step-by-Step: Define hive strength and inspection/acceptance rights.
Map placements, access and water; confirm counts and dates.
Agree no-spray windows and notification protocol.
Deliver, inspect, and sign acceptance checklists.
Monitor and document; incident log if problems arise.
Context & Narrative:
A good pollination season reads like a logistics plan: neat lines of hives where bees actually forage, clear tracks for vehicles, and a shared calendar for sprays and irrigations. It starts with language. ‘Eight-frame strength’ means frames covered with adult bees—not a guess. Acceptance happens at delivery, not weeks later; both parties sign and photograph. Water is placed sensibly so bees don’t abandon the crop for a carp pond a field away. 

Sprays are the sensitive bit. A notification protocol—who calls whom, how long before, what to do if weather shifts—prevents last-minute surprises. If an incident occurs, resist the blame dance; freeze the scene and document: time, products, wind, photos of bee kill and labels, samples if permitted. The contract provides the path from there. Beekeepers who run a grown-up playbook get invited back; growers who do the same get reliable bees. Everyone sleeps better during bloom.
Evidence Highlights: Strength definitions and acceptance checks reduce disputes.
Mapped placements and on-site water improve pollination efficiency.
Notification/no-spray clauses reduce spray incidents and losses.
Incident logs with photos and timings support fair resolution.
Common Pitfalls: Unmapped placements leading to poor coverage.

Callouts.text: Use a one-page acceptance form with photo boxes and signatures.

FAQs.a: Often ≥8 frames of adult bees per hive; agree locally and put it in writing.

FAQs.q: How much lead time for sprays?
FAQs.a: Agree a minimum (e.g., 24–48 h) with a named contact chain.

Seasonality & Climate: Bloom windows are tight; align deliveries with actual bud stages. Heat and wind alter bee flight—adjust placements accordingly.
